Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Investigating Seasonal and Interannual Variability of Central Asia Paleo-Hydroclimate
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award uses funds, under the auspices of the EArly-concept Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) program, for a project aimed at establishing a Uranium-Thorium based age model for stalagmites from Kyrgyzstan, Central Asia, generating preliminary proxy data, and calibrating environmental proxies against drip water chemistry from caves.

The overall science goal is to use the results of this research to help improve the understanding of mid-latitude hydroclimate response to rapid climate changes on a variety of timescales. The project also has an educational goal of providing training for two Hispanic-American undergraduate students who are already working in the researcher's lab as research assistants.

Specifically, project funds will support several analyses such as cave drip water chemistry, trace elements, fluorescence emission and intensity, delta 18-Oxygen and delta 13-Carbon, and stalagmite carbonate mineralogy as well as development of a U-Th based age model and the collection of cave drip waters.

The project activities fit well into the potentially transformative, high-risk, and exploratory nature of the EAGER program because they are inherently interdisciplinary and rely on untested ideas and techniques. The analytical activities of the study are novel and thus would likely not fare well in the regular merit review process, especially without some preliminary data.

If successful, this project could have a significant impact on the field of paleoclimatology by providing a chronology and time series from a new natural data archive in an area sensitive to hydrologic change on varying timescales. The project could lead to novel and transformative ways to explore hydroclimate studies in collaboration with other science disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this research was to develop a better understanding of how semi-arid climate zones responded to past changes in climate forcings. Reconstruction of past climate changes relies on climate archives. Stalagmites, calcareous cave deposits, are used as a regional hydroclimate archive. Analyses of oxygen and carbon isotope ratios and chemical composition of stalagmites provide insights into regional hydroclimate changes. One of the biggest challenges in climate reconstruction of arid and semi-arid regions is the lack or the limited numbers of high resolution climate archives, including stalagmites.

The major outcome of this exploratory research was to test the quality of stalagmites from Kyrgyzstan (located in Central Asia) and to create a high resolution hydroclimate record of Central Asia, a semi-arid climate zone. The research includes field trips to Kyrgyzstan where temperature and humidity sensors were installed in the research cave and cave air temperature and humidity data, drip water and stalagmites were collected. The results of U-Th based age determinations show that the Kyrgyz stalagmites cover several geological episodes of rapid global climate changes and times when global temperature was significantly high than today. Exploratory analyses of oxygen and carbon isotope ratios and concentration of Ba, Ca, Mg, P, Sr, and U (proxies for hydroclimate reconstruction) in selected stalagmite segments indicate decadally resolved changes in precipitation and moisture sources.

The proxy data generated from the Kyrgyz stalagmites reveal that the hydroclimate of Central Asia is sensitive to freshwater and radiative forcings. Superimposed to the mean state hydroclimate changes that occurred in response to climate forcings, the proxy records indicate changes in decadal-to-centennial scaled precipitation variability.

Because high quality climate archives from arid and semi-arid climate zones are rare and, as a result, the knowledge gap is relatively large, the new record from Central Asia provides important insights into the hydroclimate sensitivity of semi-arid region to changes in climate forcings.
